tossups.question: In a novel, a boy stops hearing the cry of this creature after he witnesses a man burying a chest with a heart inside. A seer in a novel titled after this creature changes her first name after tasting the pure water of Malta. The protagonist of a novel imagines himself to be this creature making a "meaningless, ugly sound" while isolating himself in a well. While working at a wig factory, May Kasahara writes letters to a person she calls Mr. [this creature] that separates the chapters of a novel. For 10 points, name this creature which titles a novel where Kumiko tasks Toru Okada to look for their lost cat, a "chronicle" by Haruki Murakami.
tossups.answer: wind-up bird [or The Wind-up Bird Chronicle; or nejimakidori; prompt on bird]

tossups.question: A piece in this style includes four sections with titles like "Good times coming" and "Good times have come." Another piece in this style opens with both hands playing the phrase (read slowly) "D E C A [pause] B G." A composer in this style included the tempo marking "Not fast" in pieces like "The Nonpareil." Several pieces in this style appeared in the now-lost opera A Guest of Honor. John Stillwell Stark published pieces in this style like "Frogs Legs" by James Scott, who was one of the "Big Three" composers in this style alongside Joseph Lamb. A piano piece in this style was inspired by a Black club in Sedalia, Missouri. For 10 points, name this syncopated style of music that includes "Maple Leaf" and "The Entertainer" by Scott Joplin.
tossups.answer: ragtime

tossups.question: The dimension of one of these things must be 496 for a superstring theory to make sense, as discovered by Green and Schwarz. Particles in a QFT are classified as one of the unitary irreducible representations of one of these structures in Wigner's (VIG-nurrz) classification. The no-ghost theorem was used to prove that the moonshine module was connected to a “sporadic” example of these mathematical structures termed the “monster.” The internal symmetries of the Standard Model are represented by the direct product of three of these mathematical structures, SU(3), SU(2) and U(1). A gauge theory's gauge transformations form a type of these structures named for Sophus Lie (LEE). Abelian (ah-BEE-lee-uhn) gauge theories have symmetries that form a commutative one of these structures. For 10 points, what mathematical structures contrasted with rings and fields underpin much of QFT?
tossups.answer: groups [accept specific types of groups like gauge groups or orthogonal groups or the Poincare group or Lie groups or commutative groups or symmetry groups; prompt on gauge symmetry]

tossups.question: A character from the Charles Dickens novel Barnaby Rudge names a mostly plain cloth form of these items prominent in the "Dolly Varden" craze. tossups.question: A thinker distinguished between "embodied," "objectified," and "institutionalized" varieties of this concept in a paper entitled "The Forms of [this concept]." A book about a form of this concept contrasts the "bridging" and "bonding" types based on whether they reinforce group identities. A form of this concept is unconsciously signaled through tendencies to act in a particular way, called habitus. Possessing more of a form of this concept allows agents to determine taste in society according to Pierre Bourdieu's (BORR-dooz) Distinction. The decline of community organizations is linked to a decline of its "social" form in Robert Putnam's Bowling Alone. For 10 points, identify this concept whose economic variety is, along with labor and land, one of the primary factors of production.
tossups.answer: capital [or cultural capital; or social capital]

tossups.question: In the Pelasgian (peh-las-gee-an) creation myth, this god created the serpent Ophion (oh-fee-on) under the supervision of Eurynome (yur-i-noh-me). A son of this deity named Butes (boo-tehs) threw himself down a well as punishment for assaulting the Maenad (mee-nad) Coronis (kor-oh-niss). This god won a contest against Helios for who could strip a man of his clothes fastest. In Rome this god was known as Aquilo (ah-quee-loh). This god mated with the mares of Ericthonius (ehr-ik-thoh-nee-us) and produced 12 of the fastest horses in the world. Phineus's (fin-eh-oos) wife Cleopatra was a daughter of this god, and another daughter of this god was the goddess Chione (kee-ohn). A land named for being beyond this god's land was a mythical land of plenty. For 10 points, name this Greek god of the north wind.
tossups.answer: Boreas

tossups.question: An author with this surname wrote about a dancer who moves to Naples, but is forced to stop dancing when a foot blister becomes infected from glue in a shoebox. That novel by an author with this surname ends with David Knight and Alabama Beggs dumping ashtrays after a party. In a novel by an author with this surname, affairs with Mr. Bloeckman and Dorothy Raycroft cause conflict in the marriage between Gloria Gilbert and her disinherited alcoholic husband. An author with this surname wrote Save Me the Waltz and moaned under anesthesia that their child would be a "beautiful little fool," which their husband copied directly into Daisy Buchanan's dialogue. tossups.answer: Fitzgerald [accept Zelda Fitzgerald; accept F. Scott Fitzgerald or Francis Scott Key Fitzgerald; prompt on Zelda Sayre with "What is her married name?"]

tossups.question: ISFET transistors are used as these components. Continuous immersion in liquid maintains a leached layer that is essential to a hemispherical class of these components. In non-aqueous conditions, these components may be calibrated against a ferrocene (FAIR-oh-seen) standard. Polarizable examples of these components have a capacitance modeled by the Gouy-Chapman model, which assumes a diffuse double layer. Ion-selective examples of these components are used in pH meters, and their strength is standardized relative to the formation of H2. At equilibrium, the Nernst equation states that the choice of these components determines the potential of a system. Redox half-reactions occur at, for 10 points, what components of an electrochemical cell, which carry current into a reaction?
tossups.answer: electrodes [accept cathodes or anodes; accept reference or quasi-reference electrodes, ion-selective electrodes, or glass electrodes; prompt on ISE; prompt on voltaic cells, galvanic cells, or electrochemical cells with “what subcomponents of a cell?”; prompt on answers indicating a device that measures pH, like pH meter before "pH meter" is read, by asking "which component of the pH meter?"]

tossups.question: Feroz Shah Tuhglaq transported a monument created by this ruler using reed rafts from the village of Tobra and reinstalled it near his namesake Kotla. George Turnour confused this ruler with Tissa of Anuradhapura (AH-nur-RA-DHA-poour-uh) because they both shared the same epithet of "Devanampiya" (deh-van-am-PEE-yuh) in the Mahavamsa. James Prinsep was the first European to translate inscriptions made by this ruler that were written in Prakrit. A horse, an ox, an elephant, and a lion surround the base of a capital constructed by this ruler that was found underneath a stupa at Sarnath. This ruler stated that "All men are my children" for a rock inscription named after the state of Kalinga. For 10 points, name this Mauryan emperor whose many rock and pillar edicts detail his conversion to Buddhism.
tossups.answer: Ashoka the Great

tossups.question: Superstition claims couples who climb this city's Cerro Monserrate (mone-say-RAH-tay) never marry. Bargoers in this city's Zona Rosa throw metal disks at gunpowder-filled targets in the game of tejo (TAY-hoe). Tourists can stroll markets in this city's Usaquén (oo-sah-KEN) district before seeing its historic Candelaria neighborhood. This city's Museum of Gold contains relics thrown into Lake Guatavita by the Muisca (MWEES-kah) people, a story of which inspired the name of this city's El Dorado Airport. This city was rebuilt from riots after its former Mayor Jorge Gaitán was assassinated here. A painting of an obese, child Mona Lisa is found in this city's Fernando Botero Museum. This capital city's Palace of Justice was sieged by Pablo Escobar. For 10 points, name this capital of Colombia.
tossups.answer: Bogotá

tossups.question: A 2015 paper by Matthew Fisher claims that quantum correlations between neural firing may occur due to entanglement between these two ions in Posner clusters. Precipitation of urate and a salt of these two ions causes nephropathy (neff-rop-uh-thee) as a side effect of tumor lysis syndrome. Micelles (my-cells) of casein (case-in) are stabilized by these two ions. By increasing serum levels of one of these ions, parathyroid hormone lowers levels of the other, since one precipitates the other. Nanocrystals composed of these two ions mineralize on an organic matrix of mostly collagen to form hydroxyapatite (high-droxy-app-uh-tight). For 10 points, name these two ions, a cation found in bone, and an anion released by the hydrolysis of ATP.
tossups.answer: calcium and phosphate [accept Ca2+ in place of calcium; accept PO43- in place of phosphate]

tossups.question: One state was forced to abandon a plan for this goal in the Humiliation of Olmütz. The "question" of whether this goal would be pursued in its "greater" or "lesser" form was resolved following the Peace of Prague. One legislative body pursuing this goal was created following the March Revolution and was led by Heinrich von Gagern. Though he was supportive of this goal, a "crown from the gutter" was rejected by Friedrich Wilhelm (VIL-helm) IV after an offer by the Frankfurt Parliament trying to achieve this goal. Austria's defeat in the Seven Weeks' War resulted in its exclusion from this goal, which was achieved five years later in the coronation of Wilhelm I in the Palace of Versailles. For 10 points, name this goal achieved after the Franco-Prussian War by Otto von Bismarck.
tossups.answer: German unification [or equivalents; do not accept anything mentioning "reunification"]

tossups.question: A novel titled for one of these people features a hunchback who sells the narrator and the title character vellum charms. That person of this type is adopted by the narrator's family after her carriage strikes a lime tree. One of these people forces Aubrey to "swear by all your soul reveres, by all your nature fears" to not reveal the death of a nobleman to Greek bandits. The peasant girl Ianthe is killed by one of these people who adopts the title of Earl of Marsden after dying as Lord Ruthven in a John Polidori novel. One of these people is scarred by a bread wafer, but is restored to health after Quincey Morris kills one of these people with a kukri. For 10 points, Jonathan Harker and Dr. Van Helsing help kill what kind of title creature in Bram Stoker's Dracula?
tossups.answer: vampires (The novel in the first two clues is Carmilla)

tossups.question: Medieval European scholars considered the Emerald Tablet to be the origin of this field, which Jabir ibn Hayyan (jah-behr ib-neh hie-awn) outlined in the Book of Explanation. The Cantong Qi (can-toh-ng chee) is the most complete summary of the Chinese form of this field. The Islamic form of this field sought to achieve takwin. The Daoist (dow-ist) practice of Neidan (nay-dawn) is usually translated as the "internal" form of this practice. Practitioners of this field caused Qin Shi Huang (chin shee hw-awn-g) to suffer mercury poisoning. This practice's highest goal was to achieve immortality by creating the philosopher's stone. For 10 points, name this practice, which sought to transmute lower metals, like lead, into gold.
tossups.answer: alchemy [prompt on chemistry or science; prompt on answers about seaking eternal life]

tossups.question: While opening a chest with a blue and gold crown, a woman stares at this figure's "shadow of death" in one painting. This figure is red-headed in a painting that Charles Dickens lambasted for its depiction of a woman painted "so horrible in her ugliness" as to appear in the "lowest gin-shop in England". A boy holding a water bowl stares at this figure as he's kissed by his mother, who is modeled on Mary Hodgkinson, in that painting. An artist worked on both a painting of this figure and The Lady of Shalott with Edward Robert Hughes. In that painting, this figure holds a lantern in his left hand and knocks with his right; that William Holman Hunt painting is The Light of the World. tossups.answer: Jesus Christ [accept either underlined portion; accept Christ in the House of his Parents] (The leadin refers to William Holman Hunt's painting The Shadow of Death)

tossups.question: In the book New York Exposed, Daniel Czitrom claims Charles Parkhurst's investigations into this profession launched the Progressive Era. Alice Stebbins Wells helped encourage women in this profession to work with children. While in Wichita, O.W. Wilson expanded the usage of radios in this profession. The "father" of this profession popularized Hans Gross in America and commissioned John Larson to invent the polygraph; that man was August Vollmer. Martin Toole began a union for this profession as a "Fraternal Order." An anarchist-made pipe bomb killed seven members of this profession and ignited the Haymarket Riots. For 10 points, name this profession whose members cracked down on protests and enforced warrants during the Gilded Age.
tossups.answer: police officers [or cops; or law enforcement]

tossups.question: This poet used many struck-out words and mathematical calculations in notes on the theatrical presentation of a project called The Book. The speaker mourns, "Sad flesh. And I've read all the books." in this poet's "Sea Breeze." This poet wrote of "eternal circumstances / from the depth of a shipwreck" in a poem where "All thought emits" the title event. This poet wrote a 20-page poem which "periodically accelerates or slows the movement" by using varied whitespace and typefaces. The speaker waits to see "the shade you became" in a poem by this poet which begins, "These nymphs I would perpetuate." For 10 points, name this French Symbolist poet of "A throw of the dice will never abolish chance," who inspired a Debussy prelude with their poem "Afternoon of a Faun."
tossups.answer: Stéphane Mallarmé [or Étienne Mallarmé]

tossups.question: Bas van Fraassen's controversial special reflection principle holds that, for a rational agent, these quantities are constant throughout time, which implies that they do not violate synchronic coherence. Richard Jeffrey formulated a "radical" approach to these quantities, quipping "it's [these things] all the way down." Frank Ramsey argued it is irrational for an agent to violate their namesake axioms because doing so would mean a Dutch book could be constructed against them. When learning new information, conditionalization can be used to update them given a prior. In Bayesian epistemology, this type of quantity represents a degree of belief. For 10 points, name these quantities which describe how likely it is that a proposition is true.
tossups.answer: probabilities [or word forms like probability; or subjective probabilities; accept prior probability; accept conditional probabilities; accept probabilism; accept degrees of belief before "degree of belief"; accept credences; accept probability axioms or axioms of probability; prompt on confidence with "what type of quantity is confidence expressed as?"; prompt on prior]

tossups.question: To create the effect of rainstorms in this film, pen ink was added to firehose water to create darker water. This film normalized pointing the camera directly at the sun to create a lens flare effect. A character earlier accused of stealing daggers walks away from a ruined temple carrying an orphaned baby at the end of this film. A character in this film maniacally laughs while recalling "crossing swords" 22 times with a dead man who later speaks through a medium. An "effect" named for this film was inspired by its plot of a bandit and a woodcutter's conflicting stories of the death of a samurai. An algorithm called the "automatic" form of this operation can approximate the multivariate "directional" form of it. The (emphasize) inverse of this operation can be computed numerically with the Newton-Cotes formula, a quadrature method that generalizes Simpson's rule. tossups.answer: numerical differentiation [accept word forms; accept taking a derivative or directional derivative; accept gradient, accept specific orders or types of derivatives, such as first derivative, accept Laplacian]

tossups.question: A holder of this title brought back a "chair of brass" in a naval expedition recorded by Pedro Sarmiento de Gamboa. Victoria de la Jara posited that a black flower with four petals was the tocapu that represented the holder of this title. One holder of this title earned his epithet after stone soldiers helped him repel an invasion by the Chanka. A holder of this title constructed the Sacsayhuaman (sahck-sigh-HWAH-man) fortress in a city which was laid out in the shape of a puma. When Vicente de Valverde offered a holder of this title the Bible, he threw it to the floor. The last holder of this title offered up a room full of gold after losing the Battle of Cajamarca. For 10 points, Pachacuti held what title whose holders ruled an Andean empire?
tossups.answer: Incan Emperor [accept word answers indicating the Emperor of the Inca people; or Sapa Inca]

bonuses.leadin: William Safire was a speechwriter for this President. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: failure of Apollo 11 [or answers mentioning the Apollo 11 astronauts being stranded on the Moon; or the Apollo 11 astronauts dying during the mission; or failure of the moon landing; prompt on Moon disaster or similar answers]
parts: Name this President whom Safire had previously worked for in his failed 1960 presidential campaign. Safire coined the phrase "nattering nabobs of negativism" for this man's Vice-President, Spiro Agnew.
Safire was the publicist overseeing what became this event in a "model house" at the American National Exhibition, featuring then-Vice President Nixon and Nikita Khrushchev discussing technology.

Nixon never used a speech by Safire that would have been delivered had this event taken place. The individuals involved in this hypothetical event are described in that speech as "epic men of flesh and blood."

bonuses.leadin: In a poem, one of these creatures is compared to "Butterflies, off Banks of Noon" that "Leap plashless as they swim" after being offered a crumb by the speaker. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: birds [do not accept or prompt on specific types of birds]
my brain [accept "I felt a Funeral, in my Brain"]
parts: Name these creatures who titles a poem where he "came down the Walk." The speaker of another poem observes that "sore must be the storm / That could abash" one of these creatures.
This poet of "A Bird came down the Walk" describes a bird that "sings the tune without the words" in their poem "Hope is the Thing with Feathers."

The speaker of a Dickinson poem says they could have "seen [this thing] – go round – / They might as wise have lodged a Bird." Mourners tread "to and fro" in a Dickinson poem titled for this thing which ends with the speaker dropping down after "a Plank in Reason, broke."

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the politics behind the proposed European Super League:
answers_sanitized: JP Morgan Chase [accept either underlined portion]
Al Nahyan [or Al Nohayan; prompt on Al Falahi]
parts: Florentino Pérez incorporated the Super League as an LLC in this country. In 2017, a football club in this country closed its stadium in protest of government violence towards Carles Puigdemont (PWEEG-de-mont) and other supporters of Catalan Independence.
The ESL would have been bankrolled by this company. This bank's CEO, Jamie Dimon (DIE-mun), denied notions that he would be Biden's Secretary of the Treasury.

This family's Sheikh Mansour has been praised as the unlikely savior of football for pulling Manchester City out of the league early. This family's Sheikh Zayed united the seven emirates of the UAE in the 1970s.

bonuses.leadin: This complex is partially activated by an adaptor protein coded by the PYCARD gene, called ASC. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: inflammasome [prompt on pyroptosome by asking for the more common name]
caspases [accept procaspases or procaspase 9; accept cysteine-aspartic proteases or cysteine aspartases]
macrophages [prompt on white blood cells or leukocytes]
parts: Name this complex, which plays a key role in signalling a form of cytokine-releasing programmed cell death called pyroptosis (pie-rop-TOH-sis). It releases interleukins 1 and 18.

ASC, like other proteins containing a CARD domain, is involved in the recruitment of these proteins. The inactivated forms of these proteins have death effector domains, and one of them numbered 9 is activated by the cytochrome c-formed apoptosome (ey-POP-toe-zome).
ASC is primarily found in the nuclei of these "large eater" cells, which are involved in phagocytosis (FAY-go-sigh-toe-sis) of foreign materials during the immune response.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Catholic far right through the work of E. Michael Jones, for 10 points each.
answers_sanitized: The City of God [or On the City of God Against the Pagans; or De civitate Dei contra paganos]
Fraternal Society of Saint Pius X ("the tenth") [or FSSPX or SSPX; or Fraternitas Sacerdotalis Sancti Pii X]
parts: Jones's theology centers on this Greek word that he uses to mean a sort of "universal order" opposed by "deviants." In the Gospel of John's declaration that "In the beginning was the Word," "Word" is translated from this Greek word.

Jones borrowed a term from this book to title his Libido Dominandi (lee-bee-doh doh-mee-nahn-dee), subtitled "Sexual Liberation and Political Control." This book allegorizes history as a battle between an earthly municipality and New Jerusalem.

Despite their similarities, Jones has accused this traditionalist fraternal organization of schism (SKIZ-um). This organization founded by Marcel Lefebvre (mar-sel leh-feh-vruh) takes its name from an early 20th century anti-modernist pope.

bonuses.leadin: A hairy brown dog lies on the ground facing to the left below the left-most figure in a version of this painting. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: newspapers [or journals; or Le Journal; prompt on papers] (The French word for "day," jour, is formed by folding a newspaper headlined Le Journal)
parts: Name this Cubist painting depicting three figures dressed as Pierrot, Harlequin, and a friar, believed to be its artist, Guillaume Apollinaire, and Max Jacob respectively. Its central figure holds a guitar.
This Spanish painter of Three Musicians painted an old man playing a guitar in one of the most iconic paintings from his "Blue Period."

Picasso's fellow cubist Juan Gris painted a guitar paired with one of these things, which he paired with a bottle of rum and a fruit dish in other paintings. One of these things displaying the French word for "day" appears under a tree in Joan Miro's (zho-AHN mee-ROH's) The Tilled Field.

bonuses.leadin: The Grand Fleet was based in a body of water in this island group. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: scuttling of the High Seas Fleet [accept answers indicating the scuttling of the Imperial German Navy]
Armistice of 11 November 1918 [or Armistice of Compiègne]
parts: Name this island group which contains Scapa Flow, a sheltered body of water. The Royal Navy was moved to this island group from bases on the English Channel at the start of the First World War to better control the North Sea.

Due to this action, Scapa Flow is the source for much of the world's steel with low levels of background radiation. This action made Scapa Flow a popular diving location and was taken a week before the signing of the Treaty of Versailles.
The High Seas Fleet was interned at Scapa Flow due to this agreement which ended fighting between Germany and the Allies. Veterans Day commemorates the signing of this agreement.

bonuses.leadin: During this battle, the Scotsman Douglas kills Shirly, Stafford, Blunt, and numerous other men dressed as "counterfeit[s]" of the King. For 10 points each-
answers_sanitized: Hotspur [or Henry Percy; prompt on Henry or Harry]
parts: Name this climactic battle from a Shakespeare history play. During this battle, Worcester (WUS-tur) and Northumberland are defeated, while Prince Hal repairs his reputation by saving the King from Douglas.
This quick-tempered character is killed by his rival Hal at Shrewsbury. His outrage at Henry IV's refusal to ransom Edmund Mortimer from the Welsh sparked his rebellion against the king.

This rotund knight is summoned from the Boar's Head tavern to fight at Shrewsbury, where he describes honor as "a mere scutcheon." This man fittingly claims to have killed Hotspur despite actually playing dead during the battle.

bonuses.leadin: By acting as a speedometer, a "zero-area" interferometer named for this scientist may be able to surpass the standard quantum limit for detecting gravitational waves. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Georges Sagnac [or Sagnac interferometer or Sagnac effect]
gyroscopes [or ring laser gyroscopes or fiber optic gyroscopes or London moment gyroscopes]
optical fibers [or fiber optic cables or fiber optic gyroscopes; prompt on fibers]
parts: Name this scientist, whose names an effect where light travelling in opposite directions in a spinning interferometer will travel the same distance in different times.

The Sagnac (san-YAK) effect allowed for the development of non-mechanical examples of these devices, like the ring laser type. Four of these objects were used to detect frame-dragging in the Gravity Probe B experiment.
Another common non-mechanical gyroscope sends light through these thin glass cables. They act as waveguides, allowing high speed data transfer for cable and internet purposes.

bonuses.leadin: This composer's Piano Concerto in C-sharp minor is dedicated to Venezuelan composer Teresa Carreño. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this American composer who incorporated folksongs and Creole tunes into the opera Cabildo. This composer quoted the Celtic song "Dark is the Night!" in an E-minor symphony subtitled "Gaelic."

Amy Beach was a member of a group of six composers named for this city that included Edward MacDowell. Serge Koussevitzky was a long time director of this city's orchestra, which performs at Tanglewood each summer.

Beach's Gaelic Symphony was influenced by the work of this European composer. He was himself inspired by African-American composer Harry Burleigh's singing of spirituals to write his Symphony "From the New World."

bonuses.leadin: An early method used to extract this resource, the shaduf, consists of a bucket hung on one end of a seesaw. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: water [accept obvious equivalents like river water]
Taklamakan Desert [prompt on the Tarim Basin]
parts: Name this resource. Ancient Egyptians relied on the flooding of the Nile in order to provide this resource to their crops.

The karez well system was historically used to extract water from the Turpan Oasis in this desert. The Iranian Shule Kingdom was centered in this desert's city of Kashgar, which was an important stop along the Silk Road.

Early Persians developed these underground aqueducts to channel water from aquifers down slopes to their crops. Afghanistan's Wardak province contains one of these structures that has been in use for over 300 years.

bonuses.leadin: This character's father angrily stands up before collapsing and dying, accidentally slapping him in the process. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Zeno Cosini [accept either underlined portion; accept The Confessions of Zeno or Zeno's Conscience or La coscienza di Zeno]
If on a Winter's Night a Traveller [or Se una notte d'inverno un viaggiatore]
parts: Name this businessman from Trieste, who is addicted to smoking "last cigarettes" which are never his last. The frame story to a novel consists of this character's psychiatrist publishing a diary of his namesake "confessions."

The name "Zeno of Elea" is used as a codeword during a luggage exchange gone wrong in this novel's first chapter. This novel features the search for Silas Flannery, a detective fiction writer whose work is so formulaic that it can be written by machines.
The creator of the aforementioned Zeno, Italo Svevo, shares his first name with this author of If on a Winter's Night a Traveller.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the legend of Urashima Taro (ur-ah-shee-ma tah-roh). For 10 points each:
parts: In most versions of the legend, Urashima Taro falls in love with either Tokoyo (toh-koi-yoh) or Otohime (oh-toh-hee-may), goddesses of this domain. This domain is ruled over by the dragon-like kami Ryujin (ree-oo-jeen).

The story of Urashima Taro ends with him experiencing this fate when he opens a magic jewel box after living in the underwater Dragon Palace for hundreds of years. In a similar story, the Irish hero Oisin (oh-sheen) meets this fate after he dismounts his horse and touches the ground.
Urashima Taro is frequently compared to this American literary folk character, who disappears in the Catskill Mountains for 20 years, sleeping through the American Revolution.

bonuses.leadin: Various highly substituted derivatives of cubane function as effective examples of these compounds. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: explosives [accept any answer that indicates the molecule can explode or detonate; accept rocket propellants or similar descriptive answers]
phenol [or benzenol or carbolic acid; prompt on hydroxybenzene]
parts: Name or describe these compounds compared based on sensitivity and their relative effectiveness. A common example of these compounds is RDX, which is mixed with binders in composition C.
Explosives are rated in effectiveness relative to TNT, which is a toluene molecule substituted with three of this energetic functional group.
Another explosive with three nitro groups is picric acid, which is a trinitrated example of this molecule. This is the simplest aromatic alcohol.

bonuses.leadin: A scientist with this surname directed the development of WordNet. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this surname of a Harvard professor with the first and middle names George Armitage, who studied short term memory. A Yale psychologist with this surname and the first name Neal pioneered research on biofeedback.
George A. Miller's namesake law, based on his paper on this "magical number," states that the average human working memory can hold this many items, "plus or minus two."

The aforementioned George Miller paper exemplifies a 1950s "revolution" in psychology named for this adjective. A form of therapy developed by Aaron Beck is named for this adjective and the adjective "behavioral."

bonuses.leadin: The two axes on a Budyko curve are indices whose numerators are potential and actual values of this quantity. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: evapotranspiration [or ET; accept answers including both evaporation and transpiration, but do not accept just "evaporation" or "transpiration"]
parts: Name this compound term that describes the total flux of water from land or ocean surface into the atmosphere. It includes fluxes from bare surfaces and vegetation, and can be estimated using the Penman-Monteith equation.

Evapotranspiration is limited by energy at the lower left of a Budyko curve, which may lead soil to become saturated, causing the "saturation-excess" form of this phenomenon. It also has an "infilitration-excess" form.

Both axes on a Budyko curve are normalized by the rate of this process, a part of the water cycle that returns water from the atmosphere to the land or ocean surface. Rain and snow are examples of this process.

bonuses.leadin: The white marble colonnades that adorn the façade of this city's cathedral exemplify its distinctive Romanesque style. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Giotto [or Giotto di Bondone or Giottus]
parts: Name this Italian city, whose Piazza dei Miracoli also has a campanile (CAMP-ah-NEE-lay), or bell-tower, with an iconic four-degree lean.

For the Baptistery of Pisa, Nicola Pisano carved a hexagonal proto-Renaissance version of one of these structures out of marble. Nicola's son Giovanni omitted a wood board called a tester over one of these structures inspired by Roman sarcophagi for the Church of Sant'Andrea.
The campanile next to Florence Cathedral was designed by this artist, who covered its exterior in geometric decorations of polychrome marble. He also painted a fresco cycle for the Scrovegni Chapel.

bonuses.leadin: The Borovo Treasure is a set of silver wedding gifts excavated from this modern-day country where the Getaen tomb of Sveshtari was excavated. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this modern-day country where the construction of the Koprinka Reservoir covered the ruins of Seuthopolis. The oldest gold artifacts in world history were excavated from a necropolis in this country.

Bulgarian Khans worshipped near a 100-meter tall rock carving of a horseman crushing one of these animals at Madara. Trevor Bryce claims the first coat-of-arms of Europe in Mycenae depicted one of these animals, which appeared on gates to the entrance of Hattusa.
Monks at Bulgaria's Tarnovo monastery founded a namesake school for creating these objects. Leo III proposed destroying these Orthodox religious objects in the 8th century.

bonuses.leadin: The psychologists D.J. West and Anneli Taube are referenced several times in this novel's footnotes. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Kiss of the Spider Woman [or El beso de la mujer araña]
Manuel Puig [or Juan Manuel Puig Delledonne]
Molina's mother [or Molina's mom; prompt on Molina's parent or relative]
parts: Name this novel. Another of this novel's footnotes contains a press book for the Tobis-Berlin film Her Real Glory, which describes how Leni Lamiasson adheres to Nazi feminine ideals.
Many of those footnotes address Molina's sexual identity, which was likely inspired by the experiences of this homosexual author of Kiss of the Spider Woman.

One of the footnotes uses Oscar Fenichel's work to explain how this unnamed character heavily influences Molina's sexuality. Molina has the warden give him bags of food so he can make it appear to Valentin that this person visited him.

bonuses.leadin: This woman dedicated her best-known work to Talleyrand, who, in a report to the National Assembly, had argued that women should receive only a domestic education. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author who advocated for women's education in that 1792 book. "Hints" for the second part to that book were published after her early death by her partner William Godwin.

Wollstonecraft's Vindication of the Rights of Women savagely attacks this earlier thinker, who argued that women's education should serve to entertain men in Émile. This Genevan wrote The Social Contract.

This early feminist author of A Serious Proposal to the Ladies may have inspired the opening to The Social Contract with her quote "If all Men are born free, how is it that all Women are born slaves?"

bonuses.leadin: This organization's name is cryptically mentioned in the fourth act of a play in which Niccolò masquerades as a courier in order to kill the evil Angelo, Duke of Squamuglia. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: V-2 rockets [accept either underlined portion; accept missiles or CIM-10 Bomarc]
parts: Name this organization. Its logo is featured in an advertisement for "sophisticated fun" with Kirby posted in a bathroom latrine at The Scope, as well as at a herbalist shop in Chinatown.
The Tristero organization is featured in this Thomas Pynchon novel which ends before the title event, an auction attended by Genghis Cohen and Oedipa Maas, can occur.

Events in Thomas Pynchon novels like V and The Crying of Lot 49 were inspired by his time working as a writer for companies that produced these objects. The first line of another of his novels references these objects in describing how "a screaming comes across the sky."
